addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable S
r
Francis Walsingham knight, Principall secretary to her Ma
tie
.

19
of Dec
e
b
1589
From M
r
Bodleigh at
e Hage.

page.lettertext:
It may please yo
r
H. presently after the
writing of my former heerw
t
,
e
G
en
erall states
being mette, I declared
at unto them, whiche
I was willed by my
LL
. of
e Councell, con-
erning
Ostend:
whereto I doe thinke by my
next to send yo
w
their answear.
At this present
e
Councell of state
are in Treaty
w
t
e Generall states, to have their autoritie
bothe more assured and enlarged unto them:
for
at at this instant we have advertisment,
of three or fower Garrisons
at refuse to yeld
obedience to
e Councels orders. Moreover
e Councell hath written to
e Provinces of
Utrecht,
Gelderland
and
Overissel,
requiring eche of
them to name three severall persons to
e go-
vernment of their Provinces of w
ch
according
to
e 24 Article of their Contract w
t
her
Ma
tie
e Councell of state is to elect one. Whether
they will resolve to have one Governo
r
of all
three Provinces, as they had in time past of
Count Neuwenar
, or a particular for eche, I
can not yet perceave. It is certified
from
Strausbourgh
by some of
Trachses
familie,
to their frindes at
e Hage,
at there lye in those
quarters in
e Bishops territorie,
Coronel Damp-
martini
w
t
a charge of 1500 horse, and
Mons
r
de Lanti
sonne to
Coronel Lanti
w
t
1800 foote:
likewise
Coronel Wambach
w
t
a regiment of
Almans, and
Coronel Frentz
w
t
1500 horse,
and a 1000 shotte, whose comming was daily
there
attended by
e
D of Lorraine
, and pre-
paration made to stoppe them of their passage.
But those letters bearing date
e 1 of Dec
r
styl vet
fol.286v
signifie
at
e troupes were ready to passe
muster, and to depart immediately: whiche I
thought to impart w
t
yo
r
H. because it should
seeme by
e parties from whome and to whome
it was written, to be a true certificat.
And
so I take my humble leave.
From
e Hage 19. 89
Yo
r
H. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
Heere is certificat come,
at part of
e fort whiche
e
Enemie tooke from us by
Rees,
is caried away w
t
water, whiche hath forced the Enemie to ab
a
don
it, and to retire into a Castell adjoining, leaving
only behind a fewe boates w
t
souldiers. But it
is thought we may recover
e place w
t
force by water.
For whiche they are busied heere at this present to
take order. The towne of
Bercke
hath sent hither againe for some speedy advise to
be taken for their further relief, whiche can not be
fol.287r
done by
force of armes, but it is supposed
at there be mar-
chants of
Collen,
whiche may be induced to under-
take to vic tuall it, wheruppon it is cosulted at
this present. What is intended
by
e Magistrats of Utrecht, I can not come to un-
derstand: But they have resolved, and
e speeche
goeth
at they have put i t already in execution, to
depose their 4 ministers, or at
e lest two of them
from their function. They have often attempted
it heeretofore, but by intercession of
e Councell of
state they have forboren. It is thought nowe
at
Floreistein,
and suche others as yo
r
H. hath under-
stoode heeretofore to have bin bannished
e towne,
doe take an opportunitie to be revenged. The
cause whiche they pretend of their proceeding is,
for that those ministers continew affected to
Deventer
and his faction. For I thinke some of them of late
both
have
publickly noted
e chief magistrat to be of no
religion, in their sermons to
e people.
Count
Maurice
and
e
states of Holland
, have sent
two other ministers of these partes unto them, to
persuade them to an attonem
t
. But there is smalle
hope of any good by their endevo
rs
: so as many men
feare it will prove a preparative to a great deale
of further troble, and in
e ende
to
a defection
to
e Enemie. Dec
r
21.
